Is there also past attachment to views?
Answer: If it has not been severed.
It means that if there is prior attachment to love that has not been severed regarding this matter,
attachment to views has also not been severed.
Regarding this matter, there is also the meaning of being bound by past attachment to views.
If there is prior attachment to love that has not been severed regarding this matter, but attachment to views has already been severed,
regarding this matter, there is no meaning of being bound by past attachment to views.
Just as when the knowledge of the class of the path has already arisen, regarding dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation,
there is prior attachment to love that has not been severed.
When the knowledge of the class of the origin has already arisen, regarding dharmas not associated with attachment to views to be eliminated by the paths of cessation and the path,
there is prior attachment to love that has not been severed.
For this reason,
in this context, the general statement if it has not been severed is made.
It does not state the stage where the knowledge of the class of the path has not yet arisen.
Because in that state, there is also attachment to existence and no view.
Those who are confused about the general characteristics and whose past fetters have not been severed are necessarily bound to the events of the three times.
It is not like attachment, etc., which are explained as indeterminate.
Even if there is past bondage of view,
is there also past bondage of attachment?
The answer is: If it has already arisen and has not been severed, then it is bound.
If it has not yet arisen, or if it has arisen but has been severed, then it is not bound.
This means that if there is past arising of the fetter of view that has not been severed
there is also past arising of the fetter of attachment that has not been severed.
In this case, there is also the meaning of being bound by the past fetter of attachment.
Even if there is past arising of the fetter of view that has not been severed
the fetter of attachment has not yet arisen in relation to this.
Even if it has arisen elsewhere, it is still said to be unarisen in relation to this.
Even if it has arisen and has been severed,
in this case there is no meaning of being bound by the past fetter of attachment.
If there is bondage by the past fetter of attachment
is there also bondage by the future fetter of view?
Answer: If it has not yet been severed.
That is to say, if there is a previously arisen attachment that has not yet been severed in this matter, the view is also not yet severed.
There is also the meaning of future bondage by the view in this matter.
If there is a previously arisen attachment that has not yet been severed in this matter,
but the view has already been severed,
then there is no meaning of future bondage by the view in this matter.
The rest is as explained above.
If there is future bondage by the view, is there also past bondage by attachment?
Answer: If it has arisen previously and has not yet been severed, then there is bondage.
If it has not arisen previously, or if it has arisen but has already been severed, then there is no bondage.
That is to say, in this matter,
if there is future bondage by the view that has not yet been severed,
there is also a previously arisen attachment that has not yet been severed.
There is also the meaning of past bondage by attachment in this matter.
If there is future bondage by the view in this matter that has not yet been severed,
but the attachment has not yet arisen previously in this matter,
although it has arisen elsewhere, it is also called unarisen in this matter.
If it has already been abandoned,
then there is no meaning of past attachment-bondage in relation to this object. If there is past attachment-bondage in relation to this object,
is there also present view-bondage?
Answer: If it is present.
That is to say, if there is past attachment-bondage that has not yet been abandoned in relation to this object,
and there is also present view-bondage, then there is the meaning of present view-bondage.
If in relation to this object,ğŸ”½there is present view-bondage,ğŸ”½but there is no past attachment-bondage,
then there is no meaning of past attachment-bondage.
If there is present view-bondage,
is there also past attachment-bondage?
Answer: If it has arisen before and not yet been abandoned, then there is bondage.
If it has not arisen before, or if it has arisen but has already been abandoned, then there is no bondage.
That is to say, if there is present view-bondage in relation to this object,
and there is past attachment-bondage that has arisen before and not yet been abandoned,
There is also the meaning of being bound by past attachment to this matter.
If there is a view bond present with regard to this matter,
but the attachment bond has not yet arisen with regard to this matter,
even if it arises elsewhere, it is also called unarisen with regard to this matter.
Even if it has arisen, it has already been severed.
There is no meaning of being bound by past attachment to this matter.
If there is a past attachment bond with regard to this matter, is there also a past or present view bond?
The answer is: There are three sentences here.
There may be a past attachment bond,
but no past or present view bond.
This refers to the case where the attachment bond has arisen and not yet been severed with regard to this matter, while the view bond has already been severed.
Here, the phrase the attachment bond has arisen and not yet been severed
shows that there is a past attachment bond.
The phrase while the view bond has already been severed negates the existence of a past or present view bond.
This refers to the case where the knowledge of the origination of the aggregates has already arisen,
but with regard to dharmas not associated with the view bond severed by the path of insight into cessation and the path,
There is past attachment that has not yet been eliminated.
The cognition of the class of the path has already arisen.
Regarding dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation,
there is past attachment that has not yet been eliminated.
There may be past attachment and past views that bind,
but none in the present.
This means that regarding this matter, there is past attachment that has not yet been eliminated,
and there are views that have not yet been eliminated but are not presently manifest.
As for there is past attachment that has not yet been eliminated here,
this shows that there is past attachment.
As for there are views that have not yet been eliminated,
this shows that there are past views.
Because regarding that which has not yet been eliminated, there must be past views that bind regarding the matter that is bound.
As for but are not presently manifest,
this negates the existence of present views.
There may be past attachment that binds,
and also past and present views that bind.
This means that regarding this matter, there is past attachment that has not yet been eliminated,
and there are also views that are presently manifest.
The phrase those who have not yet abandoned the past attachment to existence
shows that there is past attachment to existence.ğŸ”½The phrase those who have present manifestation of the view-fetter
shows that there is present manifestation of the view-fetter.
The existence of the past [view-fetter] is not stated here, but is understood by implication.ğŸ”½Because if the view-fetter is present in the past, it must exist.
If there is past and present manifestation of the view-fetter,
is there also past manifestation of the attachment to existence-fetter?
The answer is: If it arose previously and has not yet been abandoned, then it is manifested.
If it did not arise previously, or if it arose previously but has already been abandoned, then it is not manifested.
The meaning of this is explained in detail as above.
If there is past manifestation of the attachment to existence-fetter with regard to a certain thing,
is there also future and present manifestation of the view-fetter?
The answer is: There are three possibilities here.
There may be past manifestation of the attachment to existence-fetter,
but no future or present manifestation of the view-fetter.
This refers to those for whom the attachment to existence-fetter arose previously and has not yet been abandoned,
while the view-fetter has already been abandoned.
The phrase those who have not yet abandoned the past attachment to existence
It shows that there is past attachment.
But the view is already severed.
It blocks the future and present views.
The rest is as previously explained.
There may be past attachment,
and there may be future views, but not present.
It means that there is attachment that was previously born and not yet severed regarding this matter.
And there is view that is not yet severed but not presently manifest.
Here, the attachment that was previously born and not yet severed
shows that there is past attachment. The view that is not yet severed
shows that there is future view.
Because regarding that which is not yet severed, there will definitely be future attachment to the bound matter.
But not presently manifest
blocks the present view.
There may be past attachment and also future and present views.
It means that there is attachment that was previously born and not yet severed regarding this matter.
And there is view that is presently manifest.
Here, the attachment that was previously born and not yet severed
It shows that there is past attachment.ğŸ”½As for those with the present manifestation of the view-fetter,
it shows that there is present view.
The future existence is not stated, but it is understood by implication.ğŸ”½Because in the future there will definitely be the present manifestation of the view-fetter.
If there is the binding of the future and present view-fetter,
is there also the binding of the past attachment-fetter?
The answer is: If it arose previously and has not yet been eliminated, then it binds.
If it did not arise previously, or if it arose previously but has already been eliminated, then it does not bind.
The meaning of this is as explained in detail above.
If there is the binding of the past attachment-fetter with regard to this object,
is there also the binding of the past and future view-fetter?
The answer is: If it has not been eliminated.
The meaning of this should be understood as above.
If there is the binding of the past and future view-fetter,
is there also the binding of the past attachment-fetter?
The answer is: If it arose previously and has not yet been eliminated, then it binds.
If it did not arise previously, or if it arose previously but has already been eliminated, then it does not bind.
The meaning of this is as explained in detail above.
If there is past attachment,
is there also past, future, and present view?
The answer is: There are three possibilities.
There may be past attachment,
but no past, future, or present view.
This refers to the case where attachment arose in the past and has not yet been eliminated,
while view has already been eliminated.
Here, attachment arose in the past and has not yet been eliminated
shows that there is past attachment, while view has already been eliminated
refutes the existence of past, future, and present view.
This refers to the case where the knowledge of the origination of the aggregates has already arisen,
but the dharmas not associated with the view eliminated by the path of seeing cessation and the path are
where attachment arose in the past and has not yet been eliminated.
The knowledge of the origination of the path has already arisen,
but the dharmas to be eliminated by cultivation have attachment that arose in the past and has not yet been eliminated.
There may be past attachment,
and past and future view, but not present.
This refers to the case where attachment arose in the past and has not yet been eliminated,ğŸ”½and
And the fetter of views has not yet been severed, but is not presently manifest.
As for the fetter of craving for existence that arose in the past and has not yet been severed,
this shows that there is the fetter of craving for existence in the past.
As for the fetter of views that has not yet been severed,
this shows that there is the fetter of views in the past and future.
As for not being presently manifest, this excludes the fetter of views being present.
There may be one who is bound by the fetter of craving for existence in the past,
and also bound by the fetter of views in the past, future, and present.
That is to say, with regard to this matter, the fetter of craving for existence arose in the past and has not yet been severed,
and also the fetter of views is presently manifest.
As for the fetter of craving for existence that arose in the past and has not yet been severed,
this shows that there is the fetter of craving for existence in the past.ğŸ”½As for the fetter of views being presently manifest,
this shows that there is the fetter of views in the present.

The existence of the fetter of views in the past and future is not stated here, but is understood by implication.ğŸ”½Because when the fetter of views is presently manifest, there must be the fetter of views in the past and future.
Even if one is bound by the fetter of views in the past, future, and present,
is one also bound by the fetter of craving for existence in the past?
If the former has not yet been eliminated, then it is bound.
If the former has not yet arisen, or if it has arisen but has already been eliminated, then it is not bound.
The meaning of this is explained in detail as before.
As with the proclivities toward the view of self and the view of extremes, so too is it with the proclivities toward the view of annihilation and the view of the two extremes.
They are all only eliminated by the path of insight in the three realms.
When attachment is opposed to them, there are seven small groups.
As with the proclivities toward the view of self,
there are also some minor differences here.
That is, the proclivity toward grasping only arises after the knowledge of the path.
There is attachment to the proclivities that have arisen previously and not yet been eliminated with regard to dharmas eliminated by cultivation.
There is past attachment,
but there is no grasping in the three times.

It is not like the proclivity toward the view of self that has arisen after the knowledge of the aggregates and the knowledge of the classes, and with regard to dharmas eliminated by the insight into cessation and the path, the proclivity toward the view of self is not associated with the proclivity.
There is attachment to the proclivities that have arisen previously and not yet been eliminated.
There is also past attachment, but there is no view in the three times.
Because the difference in meaning is slight, it is not mentioned here.
As with the small seven groups formed by opposing attachment to the proclivities toward the view of self,
Up to the knot of jealousy corresponding to the knot of stinginess, the small seven are also made according to what is appropriate.
Here, according to what is appropriate means:
Only pride and craving are common to the three realms and the five categories.
They only have contaminated objects and are not universal mental activities.
Corresponding to the latter, the small seven sentences are made.
They are all explained like craving.
Ignorance is common to the three realms and the five categories.

It has contaminated and uncontaminated objects, is universal and non-universal mental activity. View and doubt are common to the three realms and only the four categories. They are common to contaminated and uncontaminated objects, are universal and non-universal mental activities.
The two graspings are common to the three realms and only the four categories.
They have contaminated objects and are common to universal and non-universal mental activities.
Anger is only in the desire realm and is common to the five categories.
It only has contaminated objects and is not a universal mental activity.
Jealousy and stinginess are only in the desire realm and are eliminated by cultivation. They have contaminated objects and are not universal mental activities.
Thus, the knots have different degrees of breadth.
Corresponding to the latter seven sentences, there are differences.
Therefore, it is necessary to speak of according to what is appropriate.
As with the small seven, the great seven are also so. The difference is:

For the second seven sentences.ğŸ”½With present love, hatred, etc.

Next, in relation to the future and present.ğŸ”½Next, in relation to the past and future.
Next, in relation to the past, future, and present.
Next, in relation to the past.
Later, in relation to future pride, etc.
For the third seven sentences.ğŸ”½With past and present love, hatred, etc.
First, in relation to past and present pride, etc.ğŸ”½Next, in relation to the future and present.
Next, in relation to the past and future.
Next, it is paired with the past, future, and present.
Next, it is paired with the past.
Next, it is paired with the future.
Later, it is paired with the present pride, etc.
This is the fourth set of seven phrases.ğŸ”½Using future and present craving, hatred, etc.
First, it is paired with future and present pride, etc.ğŸ”½Next, it is paired with past and future.
Next, it is paired with past, future, and present.
Next, it is paired with the past.
Next, it is paired with the future.
Next, it is paired with the present.
Later, it is paired with past and present pride, etc.
This is the fifth set of seven phrases.ğŸ”½Using past and future craving, hatred, etc.
First, it is paired with past and future pride, etc.
Next, it is paired with past, future, and present.
Next, it is paired with the past.ğŸ”½Next, it is paired with the future.
Next, it is paired with the present.
Next, it is paired with the past and present.
Later, it is paired with future and present pride, etc.
This is the sixth set of seven phrases.
Using past, future, and present craving, hatred, etc.
First, it is directed towards past, future, and present pride, etc.
Next, it is directed towards the past.ğŸ”½Next, it is directed towards the future.
Next, it is directed towards the present.ğŸ”½Next, it is directed towards the past and present.
Next, it is directed towards the future and present.
Finally, it is directed towards past and future pride, etc.
This becomes the seventh set of seven phrases.
If it is explained in this way, the effort is not wasted.
It benefits the text and benefits the meaning.
Because it is not repeated.
Moreover, there are only seven sets of seven phrases.
Question: What is the difference between the single line and the small seven and the large seven?
Answer: The difference lies in the names.
That is, it is called the single line.
It is called the six.
It is called the small seven.
It is called the large seven.
Furthermore, it is called the single line because it makes questions and answers based on the single line method.
It is called the six because it makes questions and answers based on the six phrases method.
It is called the small seven because it makes questions and answers based on the seven phrases method, using one to correspond with one.
Based on seven phrases of dharmas, questions and answers are made by pairing two with one.
Up to pairing eight with one, therefore it is called the great seven.
Furthermore, questions and answers are made by pairing dissimilar dharmas with dissimilar dharmas.
Not using worldly definitions, it is called the single line.
Questions and answers are made by pairing similar dharmas with similar dharmas.
Using worldly definitions, it is called the six-fold.
Questions and answers are made by pairing dissimilar dharmas with dissimilar dharmas.
Using worldly definitions, pairing one with one, therefore it is called the small seven.
Questions and answers are made by pairing dissimilar dharmas with dissimilar dharmas.
Using worldly definitions, pairing two with one.
Up to pairing eight with one, therefore it is called the great seven.
The single line, the six-fold, the small seven, and the great seven.
These are the distinctions.
The three bonds up to the ninety-eight latent afflictions.
Within the ninety-eight latent afflictions,
how many latent afflictions does each one include?
The answer is: all should be distinguished.
Question: Why is this treatise composed?
The answer is: in order to refute other schools and reveal the correct principle.
That is to say, some say:
The natures of all dharmas are included in other natures, not in their own natures.
Like the VaibhÄá¹£ika masters.ğŸ”½They say this based on the SÅ«tra of Provisional NamesğŸ”½and on worldly discourse.
As for the SÅ«tra of Provisional Names,
it says in the sÅ«tra:
The center of all pavilions and tents is the center of the pavilions and tents.
It is the support of all the materials, able to hold them up and prevent them from scattering and falling.
Therefore it is said that the center can include them.
However, the center is different from the various materials yet is said to be able to include them.
Therefore it is known that all dharmas include other natures, not their own natures.
Other sÅ«tras also say that among the five faculties, the faculty of wisdom is the most excellent.
The faculty of wisdom can include the other four faculties.
However, the faculty of wisdom is different from the four faculties yet is said to be able to include them.
Therefore it is known that all dharmas include other natures, not their own natures.
Moreover, other sÅ«tras say:
The World-Honored One said to the householder Hastaka:ğŸ”½By what Dharma do you gather your own followers?
How do your followers accept your gathering?
The householder Hastaka said:
The World-Honored One has taught me the four means of gathering:
First, giving;
Second, kind speech;
Third, beneficial action;
Fourth, sharing the same mind.
I use these four means to gather my own followers.
My followers accept my gathering through this.
However, the householder Hastaka and his followers are different, yet he speaks of gathering the assembly.
Therefore, we know that all dharmas gather the nature of others, not their own nature.
Other sÅ«tras also say:
Right view, right thought, and right effort are included in the aggregate of wisdom.
Right mindfulness and right concentration are included in the aggregate of concentration.
However, right thought and right effort are different from the aggregate of wisdom.
Right mindfulness is different from the aggregate of concentration.
Yet it is said that they are included.
Therefore, we know that all dharmas gather the nature of others, not their own nature.
As for relying on conventional discourse,
It is said that in the world, a door bolt holds a door, threads hold together clothes, and firewood is held together.
Householders say,
I hold fields, livestock, wealth, treasures, servants, and family members. Renunciants say,
I hold a group of disciples and the requisites of robes and alms bowl.
In this way, the holder is different from what is held.
Therefore, we know that all dharmas hold other natures.
In order to stop this idea and show that all dharmas hold their own natures, which is the ultimate holding.
If holding other natures were the ultimate,
then the self-nature of one dharma should be all dharmas.
When one dharma arises, all dharmas should arise.
When one dharma ceases, all dharmas should cease.
There is also another error.
One should see that what is to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering is included in what is to be eliminated by seeing the truths of the origin, cessation, and path, and by cultivation.
When one eliminates what is to be eliminated by seeing the truth of suffering, the afflictions to be eliminated by seeing the truth of the origin, etc. should also be eliminated.
If so, then the subsequent paths of cultivation would be useless.
In order to avoid this error, it is said that all dharmas only include their own nature, which is the ultimate inclusion.
Question: If all dharmas only include their own nature and are not included in other natures,
how can the sutras quoted by the VaibhÄá¹£ikas be understood in terms of conventional discourse?
Answer: The quoted sutras are not of definitive meaning.
They are spoken with a provisional meaning in mind.
Namely, the sutras say:
The central part of all platforms and tents is the support for the platforms and tents.
It is able to hold them up.
Preventing them from scattering and falling.
Therefore, it is said that the central part is able to include them. In the sense of supporting, the term include is provisionally established.
This supports them and prevents them from scattering and falling.
Therefore, the term include is provisionally established.
It is not ultimate inclusion.
Moreover, the sutras say:
Among the five faculties, the faculty of wisdom is the most excellent.
The faculty of wisdom is able to include the other four faculties.
In the sense of skillful means, the term include is provisionally established.
Wisdom serves as the skillful means to enable the other four faculties to quickly operate and accomplish great matters.
Provisionally establishing the name inclusion.
Not the ultimate inclusion.
Moreover, the scriptures say:
Those who use the four means of embracing to embrace the assembly,
Provisionally establish the sound of embracing in order to attract them and prevent their dispersal.
By means of the four means of embracing, skillfully attracting and guiding, provisionally establishing the name embracing.
Not the ultimate embracing.
Moreover, the scriptures say:ğŸ”½Right thought and right effort are also included in the aggregate of wisdom.
Right mindfulness is also included in the aggregate of concentration.
Provisionally establishing the sound of inclusion based on the meaning of following.ğŸ”½Because right thought and right effort follow the aggregate of wisdom.
Because right mindfulness follows the aggregate of concentration.
Provisionally establishing the name inclusion.
Not the ultimate inclusion. Moreover, the worldly discussions they cite,
Saying that door hinges embrace doors, threads embrace clothing, and firewood is embraced,
Provisionally speaking of embracing based on the meaning of support.
Not the ultimate embracing.
Householders say that they embrace fields and so on.
As for those who have left the household life, it refers to gathering a retinue and so forth.
Based on the meaning of benefiting, it is provisionally called gathering.
It is not gathering in the ultimate sense.
As for the nature of gathering others, it is established as gathering based on time and causes.
It is not ultimate gathering.
As for waiting for time,ğŸ”½there are times when it can gather,
and there are times when it does not gather.
As for waiting for causes,ğŸ”½there are causes that can gather,
and there are causes that do not gather.
Therefore, it is not ultimate.
As a verse says:
Because there are causes, love arises; because there are causes, hatred arises.
In the world, there is no arising of love and hatred without causes.
As for the nature of gathering itself,
it has the meaning of gathering without waiting for time or causes.
It is ultimate gathering.
As for not waiting for time,
all dharmas do not have a time when they do not gather their own nature.
Because they never abandon their own essence at any time.
As for not waiting for causes, all dharmas gather their own nature without causes.
Because they have their own essence without waiting for causes and conditions.
If one wishes to contemplate all dharmas,
one should first contemplate the meaning of subsuming them under their intrinsic nature.
When contemplating the subsuming of all dharmas under their intrinsic nature,
what benefits are there and what merits are attained?
The answer is: removing the notion of self and the notion of unity,
cultivating the notion of dharmas and the notion of distinction is easy to fulfill.
Namely, if sentient beings have the notion of self and the notion of unity,
then afflictions such as greed, hatred, and delusion will increase.
Because of their increase, one is unable to be liberated from the calamities of birth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, and distress.
If one removes the notion of self and the notion of unity,
then one contemplates material dharmas as being like a lump of flour dough that will soon disperse and be separated.
One contemplates immaterial dharmas as not being simultaneous before and after, and as soon being ground to extinction.
One generally contemplates all conditioned dharmas,
like a ball of sand blown apart and destroyed by the wind.
Because of this, one attains the seed that is similar to the door of liberation of emptiness.
Because one contemplates conditioned dharmas as empty and non-self,
one then deeply dislikes saá¹ƒsÄra.
Therefore, they also obtain the similar seeds of the door of liberation of wishlessness.
Because they do not wish for or enjoy saá¹ƒsÄra,
they deeply wish for and enjoy nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, they also obtain the similar seeds of the door of liberation of signlessness.
Regarding these three samÄdhis,
based on the lower one gives rise to the middle, based on the middle one gives rise to the upper, and based on the upper one gives rise to wisdom.
Free from the defilements of the three realms, one attains supreme perfect enlightenment and realizes eternal quiescence.
When contemplating and observing the intrinsic nature and inclusion of all dharmas,
one attains such victorious merits and virtues.
For this reason, this treatise is composed.
Here, all should be distinguished,
referring to the three bonds up to the ninety-eight latent afflictions.
Each latent affliction is included in a different way.
Therefore, all should be distinguished.ğŸ”½It is said that among the three bonds, the bond of satkÄya-drá¹›á¹£á¹­i includes three.
This bond includes three latent afflictions among the ninety-eight latent afflictions.
It refers to the three realms' afflictions that are eliminated by seeing suffering, and the latent tendencies of the view of the transitory collection.
This is said to include the three latent tendencies according to their general types.
If specifically distinguished, those belonging to the desire realm include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the desire realm.
Those belonging to the form realm include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the form realm.
Those belonging to the formless realm include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the formless realm.
Each of these realms has distinctions of the three times.

Those belonging to the past include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the past.ğŸ”½Those belonging to the future include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the future.
Those belonging to the present include the view of the transitory collection belonging to the present.
Each of these has many moments,
which each include their own characteristics. The following should be understood accordingly.
The fetter of clinging to precepts and rituals includes six.
This fetter includes six latent tendencies among the ninety-eight latent tendencies.
It includes the latent tendencies of clinging to precepts and rituals that are eliminated by seeing suffering and the path in the three realms.
The fetter of doubt includes twelve.
This fetter includes twelve latent tendencies among the ninety-eight latent tendencies.
They are the latent afflictions abandoned by seeing suffering, origination, cessation, and the path in the three realms.
As for the three unwholesome roots, greed and hatred each include five.
This means they include the greed and hatred of the five categories in the desire realm.
The unwholesome root of delusion includes four and a small part.
This means it includes the unwholesome ignorance abandoned by seeing suffering in the desire realm and the last four categories.
As for the three taints, the desire taint includes thirty-one.
This means it includes thirty-one of the thirty-six latent afflictions in the desire realm, excluding the five ignorances.
The existence taint includes fifty-two.
This means it includes fifty-two of the sixty-two latent afflictions in the form and formless realms, excluding the ten ignorances.
The ignorance taint includes fifteen.
This means it includes the ignorance of the five categories in the three realms.
As for the four floods, the desire flood includes nineteen.
This means it includes the greed, hatred, and conceit of the five categories in the desire realm, and the four categories of doubt.
The existence flood includes twenty-eight.
That is, it includes the five types of craving and pride in the form and formless realms, and the four types of doubt in each realm.
The flood of views includes thirty-six.
That is, it includes the twelve views in each of the three realms.

That is, the view of self-existence and the extreme view each have one, the view of holding precepts and rituals has two, and the views of wrong views and attachment to views each have four, totaling twelve.
The flood of ignorance includes fifteen.
That is, it includes the five types of ignorance in each of the three realms.
The four yokes are also like this.
Although the names and meanings are different, the essence is the same.
Among the four graspings, the grasping of desire includes twenty-four.
That is, it includes the five types of craving, anger, pride, and ignorance in the desire realm, and the four types of doubt.
The grasping of views includes thirty.
That is, it includes the ten views in each of the three realms.
That is, among the previously mentioned twelve views, it excludes the two views of holding precepts and rituals and includes the remaining ten views.
The grasping of holding precepts and rituals includes six.
That is, it includes the two views of holding precepts and rituals in each of the three realms.
The grasping of self-existence includes thirty-eight.

Namely, it includes the five types of craving, pride, and ignorance in the form and formless realms, and the four types of doubt in each realm.ğŸ”½Among the four fetters, the fetters of sensual desire and ill will each include five.
Namely, it includes the five types of craving and ill will in the desire realm.
The fetter of adherence to rules and rituals includes six.
Namely, it includes the two types of adherence to rules and rituals in each of the three realms.
This fetter of adherence to false views includes twelve.
Namely, it includes the four types of adherence to false views in each of the three realms.ğŸ”½Among the five hindrances, the hindrances of sensual desire and ill will each include five.
Namely, it includes the five types of craving and ill will in the desire realm.
The hindrance of doubt includes four.
Namely, it includes the four types of doubt in the desire realm.
The remaining hindrances are not included.
Because torpor, sleep, restlessness, and remorse are of the nature of entanglements.
Among the five bonds, the bonds of craving and pride each include fifteen.
Namely, it includes the five types of craving and pride in each of the three realms.
The bond of ill will includes five.
Namely, it includes the five types of ill will in the desire realm.
The two knots of jealousy and stinginess are not included in any of the above.
This is because these two knots are not of the nature of latent tendencies.ğŸ”½Among the five lower fetters, the two knots of craving and hatred each include five.
This means that they include the craving and hatred of the five categories in the desire realm.
The knot of the view of self includes three.
This means that it includes the one view of self in each of the three realms.
The knot of clinging to precepts and vows includes six.
This means that it includes the two clingings to precepts and vows in each of the three realms.
The knot of doubt includes twelve.
This means that it includes the four categories of doubt in each of the three realms.
Among the five higher fetters, the knot of craving for form includes one small part.
This means that it includes a small part of the craving to be eliminated by cultivation in the form realm.
The knot of craving for the formless includes one small part.
This means that it includes a small part of the craving to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
The knot of agitation is not included in any of the above.
This is because it is not of the nature of latent tendencies.
The knot of pride includes two small parts.
This means that it includes a small part of the pride to be eliminated by cultivation in the form and formless realms.
The two small parts of the fetter of ignorance are:
The five views are as follows: The view of self and the extreme view each include three.
This means that they include one view of self and one extreme view in each of the three realms.
The wrong view and the view of holding a view each include twelve.
This means that they include four wrong views and four views of holding a view in each of the three realms.
The view of holding precepts and vows includes six.
This means that it includes two views of holding precepts and vows in each of the three realms.
Among the six bases of craving, the craving born from eye, ear, and body contact each include two small parts.
This means that they each include a small part of craving to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire and form realms.
The craving born from nose and tongue contact each include one small part.
This means that they each include a small part of craving to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
The craving born from mind contact includes thirteen and two small parts.
This means that it includes the first four categories in each of the three realms.
and the part of greed to be eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm, and the part of greed to be eliminated by cultivation in the desire and form realms.
Among the seven latent afflictions, the latent afflictions of greed and hatred each include five.
This means that they include the greed and hatred of the five categories in the desire realm.
The latent affliction of existence includes ten.
This means that it includes the greed of the five categories in the form and formless realms, and the pride of the five categories.
The latent afflictions of ignorance each include fifteen.
This means that it includes the pride and ignorance of the five categories in the three realms.
The latent afflictions of views include thirty-six.
This means that it includes the views of the twelve categories in the three realms.
The latent afflictions of doubt include twelve.
This means that it includes the doubts of the four categories in the three realms.
Among the nine bonds, the bonds of craving, pride, and ignorance each include fifteen.
This means that it includes the greed, pride, and ignorance of the five categories in the three realms.
The bond of hatred includes five.
This means that it includes the hatred of the five categories in the desire realm, and the views.
The bonds of grasping each include eighteen.
That is, the view-fetter includes one each from the three realms, namely the view of self-existence, the view of grasping extremes, and four wrong views.
The grasping-fetter includes two each from the three realms, namely the grasping of precepts and rituals and the four views.
The doubt-fetter includes twelve.
That is, it includes four each from the three realms.
The fetters of jealousy and stinginess are not included.
Because they are not latent tendencies.
Among the ninety-eight latent tendencies, the view of self-existence in the desire realm includes the view of self-existence in the desire realm.
Up to the ignorance eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
Includes the ignorance eliminated by cultivation in the formless realm.
Because each includes its own nature.
Question: How do all dharmas include their own nature?

Answer: One's own nature is existent, real, and obtainable with regard to one's own nature, therefore it is called inclusion.ğŸ”½One's own nature is neither different, external, separate, nor always empty with regard to one's own nature, therefore it is called inclusion.
One's own nature is not already existent, not presently existent, and not future existent with regard to one's own nature, therefore it is called inclusion.
Because the intrinsic nature neither increases nor decreases in relation to the intrinsic nature, it is called inclusion.
When the intrinsic natures of dharmas include their intrinsic natures,
it is not like taking food with the hand or pinching clothes with the index finger, etc.
However, each one grasps its own substance and prevents it from being scattered and destroyed, so it is called inclusion.
The meaning of grasping is established as the meaning of inclusion.
Therefore, the ultimate inclusion only includes the intrinsic nature.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
